title: Sprint 2: Accountable Growth — Orientation
description: Before setting your Sprint 2 goals, read through each section below to learn what this sprint is about, how it works, and what's expected. Then answer the questions to confirm your understanding. Everything in Sprint 2 builds toward one outcome: demonstrating real growth that others can verify.

questions.infoBlock:
Sprint 2 Outcome

Demonstrate development in at least one soft skill with evidence validated by someone outside yourself, while documenting specific contributions to a peer's growth.

The Big Shift: From Solo to Group

In Sprint 1, you developed a skill on your own. The only person you were accountable to was yourself — your goals, your progress, your assessment.

Sprint 2 changes that. You'll be placed in a group where your growth is interconnected with others. Your group partners' effort directly affects part of your grade, and yours affects theirs. This is accountable growth — growth that's visible to others and verified externally, not just self-reported.

Your groups will be assigned before next week's class — please expect an email with your group assignment.

The skill you're developing continues from Sprint 1, but the context changes completely. Every activity in Sprint 2 builds toward the outcome above: demonstrating real, verifiable growth.
questions.prompt: What is the biggest change in Sprint 2 compared to Sprint 1?
options: You pick a completely new skill to develop from scratch
You work in a group where collaborative accountability shapes your growth
The assignments are harder but you still work alone
You switch from professional skills to technical skills
questions.hint: Think about what 'accountable' means — who are you accountable to in Sprint 2?
questions.explanation: Sprint 2 puts you in a group. Your group partners' effort affects part of your grade, and you'll need to give and receive honest feedback. The skill you're developing continues from Sprint 1, but now with external accountability.

questions.infoBlock:
How Sprint 2 Grading Works

Sprint 2 has four grading components:

  • Goals (20%) — Individual. Your personal sprint goals.
  • Reflections (20%) — Group-averaged. Everyone in your group contributes; the average score applies to all.
  • Check-ins (20%) — Group-averaged. Outreach, documentation, and engagement activities shared across the group.
  • Demo (40%) — Individual. Your personal demonstration of growth with validation from your group.

This means 40% of your grade depends on your group's collective engagement. If your partners don't show up, it affects you. If you don't show up, it affects them.

Notice how the grading structure mirrors the sprint outcome: the Demo (40%) is where you demonstrate development, and the group-averaged components (40%) are where you document contributions to a peer's growth.
questions.prompt: Which parts of your Sprint 2 grade are group-averaged (meaning your group partners' effort affects your grade)?
questions.hint: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual. What about the other 40%?
questions.explanation: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual — your own effort. Reflections (20%) and Check-ins (20%) are group-averaged — your partners' participation matters. This means your group's collective engagement directly impacts 40% of your Sprint 2 grade.

questions.prompt: Knowing that 40% of your Sprint 2 grade is group-averaged, what does that mean for how you should approach your group from day one? What will you do to make sure your group succeeds?
questions.placeholder: Think about communication, reliability, and what you'd want from your group partners...

The student just learned that 40% of their grade is group-averaged. They're reflecting on how they'll approach group accountability. Look for specificity — vague answers like 'communicate well' should be pushed to be more concrete. Check if they address both what they'll contribute AND what they expect from others. questions.infoBlock:
The Weekly Rhythm

Sprint 2 runs from Week 5 to Week 8. Each week follows a consistent pattern:

  • Core deliverable (due Friday) — The main work product for the week
  • Check-in or documentation (due Sunday) — Accountability evidence, group documentation
  • Productive reflection (due Tuesday) — What you learned, what you'll change

This rhythm keeps you consistently engaged throughout the sprint rather than cramming at the end.
questions.prompt: What is the general weekly rhythm in Sprint 2?
options: One big assignment due at the end of each week
A core deliverable (due Fri), a check-in/documentation (due Sun), and a productive reflection (due Tue)
Only in-class activities — nothing due outside of class
questions.hint: Look at the pattern — deliverables have a consistent rhythm across weeks.
questions.explanation: Each week follows a rhythm: a core deliverable (due Friday), documentation or check-in (due Sunday), and a productive reflection (due Tuesday). This keeps you consistently engaged rather than cramming at the end.

questions.infoBlock:
What Happens Each Week

  • Week 5: Group Check-in — meet your group, establish group rules and a plan for how you'll work together. Set Sprint 2 goals and design what your evidence of growth will look like — what will you show your group to prove you actually developed your skill?
  • Week 6: Networking Preparation — prepare for the upcoming alumni networking event. Develop questions and talking points aligned with your Sprint 2 skill goal.
  • Week 7: Virtual Networking Event — speed networking on Zoom with alumni. ~12 minutes per conversation, then they rotate. Ask questions, get your ideas validated, and gather external perspectives on your growth.
  • Week 8: Demonstration with Evidence — show your growth with evidence your group partners can verify. Peer evaluation.
questions.prompt: Match each week with its main focus area:

pairs.right: Group Check-in + Goal Setting + Design Evidence

questions.hint: Sprint 2 builds from group formation → preparation → external validation → demonstration.
questions.explanation: Sprint 2 follows a deliberate progression: form your group, set goals, and design what your evidence will look like (Week 5), prepare for networking aligned with your skill goal (Week 6), engage with alumni in speed networking to validate your ideas (Week 7), then demonstrate growth with the evidence you designed (Week 8).

questions.infoBlock:
The Sprint 2 Demo: Demonstration with Evidence

In Sprint 1, your demo was a handwritten reflection that you assessed yourself. Nobody else verified your claims.

Sprint 2's demo is different: it's called Demonstration with Evidence. You still demonstrate your growth, but your group partners evaluate whether your claims hold up. They've watched your progress over 4 weeks — they know if you actually did the work.

This is where the sprint outcome comes together: you demonstrate development in at least one soft skill, with evidence validated by someone outside yourself. External validation is the core of accountable growth — your development isn't just what you say it is, it's what others can verify.
questions.prompt: What makes the Sprint 2 demo different from Sprint 1?
options: Your group partners validate your demonstrated growth — it's not just your self-assessment
You present to the whole class instead of a partner
There is no demo in Sprint 2
questions.hint: The sprint is called 'Accountable Growth' — how does accountability show up in the demo?
questions.explanation: Sprint 2's demo is 'Demonstration with Evidence.' Your growth claims need to be verified by your group partners, not just self-reported. This is the accountability element — external assessment alongside self-assessment.

questions.prompt: Reflecting on the Sprint 2 outcome — demonstrating real growth with evidence others can verify, while contributing to a peer's growth — what excites you most? What concerns you? Be honest — this reflection is for you.
